Situation1: Celebrate each other's achievements and milestones.
Expectation2: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation2: The site-wide evacuation alarm has just sounded, and you must stop everything and proceed to the muster point immediately.
Story: I was just about to finish laying the last row of bricks when my phone buzzed in my pocket. It was a message from my sister: “I got the scholarship! Can you come to the ceremony? It’s in an hour.” My heart swelled with pride—she’d worked so hard, and I’d promised I’d be there for her big moments. But before I could even reply, the site-wide evacuation alarm blared, echoing off the steel beams. Instinctively, I dropped my tools and looked to my foreman, who was already waving us toward the muster point. Site protocol was strict—no exceptions, no lingering, no personal business. My team counted on me to follow the rules, to keep everyone safe. But my mind was racing, torn between the duty to my crew and the promise I’d made as a brother. I could almost hear my sister’s voice, hopeful and excited, as I joined the line of workers shuffling toward the exit, my phone heavy in my pocket and my chest tight with indecision.
